Situation1: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Situation2: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Story: My phone buzzes with a new message from Mia: “I thought we agreed on Saturday, not Sunday?” I can almost hear the disappointment in her words. As her boyfriend, I know I should call her, clear up the misunderstanding, and reassure her that I care about our plans. But right now, I’m at my desk, headset on, listening to a customer pepper me with technical questions about our new service—questions my script barely covers. My manager expects me to handle every objection smoothly, to keep the call moving, to never say “I don’t know.” I feel my heart race as I try to sound confident, flipping through the FAQ, while Mia’s message sits unanswered. I want to be the attentive boyfriend who resolves conflicts, but I also need to be the competent telemarketer who never falters. The pressure from both sides squeezes me, and I can’t shake the feeling that I’m about to let someone down, no matter what I do next.
